text:
EU companies have created more than 4,000 new South West jobs since 2012 By HannahFinch | Posted: August 09, 2017 0 COMMENTS SHARES South West businesses say that relationships with EU firms that can bring investment is vital for prosperity EU companies have created more than 4,000 new South West jobs since 2012 X 
Copy link to paste in your message / South West businesses say that relationships with EU firms that can bring investment is vital for prosperity Comments (0) 
More than 12,600 jobs in Devon and the South West have been created and safeguarded by EU companies in the past five years, new Government figures show. 
Department for International Trade (DIT) statistics published on Tuesday, August 8 show that, between 2012/13 and 2016/17, of 407 Foreign Direct Investment projects started in the South West, 144 were started by EU firms and of the 12,020 jobs created, 4,370 new jobs were due to EU firms. 
READ MORE: There are hundreds of jobs in Devon 
Of the 17,178 existing jobs that were safeguarded by the investment, 8, 234 were due to EU businesses. 
Tim Jones, Chairman of the Devon and Cornwall Business Council, said that good relationships with businesses based in EU member states is vital for the South West. 
Mr Jones said: "There is absolutely no doubt that businesses in the South West value continuity with EU partners in relationships that have been built up over years and that cannot be easily back filled by entering the global market place. 
"We recognise that statistics around inward investment are only part of the picture. 
READ MORE: Nominate now for the Western Morning News Business Awards 
"Our businesses are involved in an integrated supply chain with businesses in the EU which is even more dependent on continuity so the effects of breaking that will be felt by businesses here even more." 
Figures for Devon and Somerset, covered by the Heart of the South West Local Enterprise Partnership, show there were 16 successful FDI (Foreign Direct Investment) projects in 2016/17 , an increase of 45% on the previous year. Through these investments 688 new jobs have been created and 1009 jobs safeguarded. 
One example is US-headquartered customer service firm Sitel which is set to create hundreds of jobs with its new workforce based in The Ship at Derriford in Plymouth. 
In addition, the LEP area has secured six 'multi-region' FDI projects, which are companies that land in more than one UK location. 
Open Britain, a campaign group advocating a soft Brexit, said the figures demonstrate the importance of staying in the EU's Single Market. 
James McGrory, Executive Director of Open Britain, said:"Liam Fox keeps talking about the great new trade deals we will do after Brexit. But his own department's figures show that investment from the European Union is vital to the economy of the South West and the whole of the UK. 
"With over 4,000 jobs created by EU investment in the South West, it beggars belief that the Government would want to take us out of the European Single Market. Doing so would create new barriers to trade, making investment less likely and putting jobs at risk. 
"To protect jobs and our economy, Ministers need to see sense and negotiate continued membership of the Single Market after the UK leaves the EU." 
Across the whole of the United Kingdom, 3,149 EU projects were responsible for creating 116,000 jobs and safeguarding 80,000 more, the figures show. NEWS
